head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #22

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #22 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: went NWbN3 to a broad Strait, sevl Is on Rt – went in the Strait 4½m. to the extreme pt on Rt witht regarding sevl openings on Lt – then entd ye lac again WNW6m. a Traverse to a pt on Rt lac spacious on both sides 1 large I. on Lt & sevl on Rt[.] (Encamp'd[.]) At least ½ this day was lost by Mr St Germaine leaving the key of the Trunk, Câve & Quadrant case at last nights' encampmt[,] this was a loss not to be retriev'd in this part, accordingly we went in search of them after he had proceeded 4 Leagues, & the wind blowing hard it was late before the Canoe arrived. Stoppages are now become so Regular, that I look for some impediment every day. One of the Indian Chiefs pass'd us to day having alter'd his mind in going to Alby Fort.

July 19 Monday. From the pt on Rt 2½m. to a pt on same side (here the lac draws more narrow) 150yds to another pt on Rt – then NWbW. to a rocky pt apparently at ye end of the lac 1m. but is a narrow neck which directly opens into ye lac Co nearly NWbW3m. to a white conspicuous rock on a pt on Lt many Is & spacious lac on Rt went near the land on Lt – then 1m. to a smooth rocky pt of an Isld on Lt – NWbN2 to the pt of an Isld on Lt lac spacious on both sides, sevl small Iss on Lt & larger ones on Rt then NNW3 to the pt of an Isld on Rt lac spacious & many Islands on both sides – NW3½ to ye pt of a small rocky Isd on Lt with burnt woods on it (lac here draws narrow) pass'd 2 Iss on Lt & I bay on Rt – NWbW1½ to a grassy pt on Rt – then entd a bold River call'd Mattauwaw, went in it wth a fresh Current in our favour 2½ to Port. de l'Oreille 146yds over a good road at the bottom of this rapid is a bay, on the bottom of which is the other Port. de l'Oreille, being both together call'd les deux Port. be l'Oreille, the last is 280yds over & tolerable road, the latter part of it much descending, both Port. are on ye Lt – from the end of last turn'd 1st pt on Rt & went 14½m. to the branch the one on the Lt we entd So leaving the Rt hand one and running Wt went in So branch 1½m. when it opens into a lac, cross'd it to a rock on a pt on Rt SEbS5m. leaving a long Grassy pt on Lt – then coasted along the Shore on Rt ¾m. to an opening on same side, then cross'd a small Bay ¾ – SbW to Port. Cyprès (as call'd by our Guide)[.] The Port. is difficult to find, being 100yds thro' long Grass, before you reach the woods, it is 1810yds over, or 1m. & 50yds. The road is good[.] (Encamp'd[.]) The River we have been in to day is a fine bold river, being in general abt 50yds over, deep water & an easy Currt from the commencemt to the branch there is no other river or creek of consequence that runs into it, so that the proper Co cannot be mistaken, the Guide says that the Branch left runs down to Lac Rouge, & is 1½ days paddle[,] & also 3 Carrying places, but I could never learn there was any passage to Portage de l'Isle by the way of lac Rouge, from the branch to ye lac, & the lac at the other end of this Port. he says is nearly dry when the water is low.

20 Tuesday. From the end of the Port. fell into ye River again & went ¾m. between 2 stony Points – from hence 1¼ to Port. à la Chutte, a Cataract of abt 30 fe[et] descent, Port. on Rt side & 106yds over – from the Port. went SWbW1½ to a rocky pt on Lt – then WSW in a lac 2m. a small Id of Stones on Rt & bay on each

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
